Award.AwardTitle: Conference Proposal: Automorphic Forms on Reductive Groups and Their Covers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support the participation of early-career, US-based researchers at the workshop "Automorphic forms on Reductive Groups and their Covers" to be held June 25-28, 2018 at the FIM Institute for Mathematical Research, at ETH Zuerich in Zurich, Switzerland. The conference will focus on recent advances in automorphic forms and automorphic representations, particularly those related to covering (metaplectic) groups. Participating researchers are from the US, Israel, Europe, South Korea, and Singapore.

Automorphic forms and automorphic representations are topics with historical origins in number theory, but recent advances have led to new and surprising connections with mathematical physics. A particular theme of the conference will be the uses of small automorphic representations in both number theory and string theory. The web site for the conference may be found at https://www.math.ethz.ch/fim/conferences/friedberg.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to support early career mathematicians
attending the conference Automorphic forms on reductive groups
and their covers: A conference in honour of Solomon Friedberg
during June, 2018 at the Institute for Mathematical
Research (FIM) at ETH in Zurich, Switzerland. In the end this
grant enabled us to support 11 young mathematicians with
interest in the area of the conference, all of them either
graduate students or postdocs in pre-tenured positions,
who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

Intellectual merit: The Langlands program a cornerstones of
modern number theory. It concerns automorphic forms, now
understood to be fundamental objects. Certain automorphic
forms on covering groups are more mysterious, yet also
very important since they appear in key constructions.
They have also appeared in a seemingly unrelated way in
mathematical physics. This conference, dealing with these
topics therefore focussed on this central issue. Most of the
speakers were from a number theory background but at least three
of the talks had mathematical physics content. Thus the
conference had an interdisciplinary component.

Broader impacts: The purpose of this grant was to broaden
participation by early career mathematicians, and in this
it was successful. We feel certain that the conference will have a
positive impact on development of personel in number theory and
potentially (due to the interdisciplinary aspect mentioned above)
also in mathematical physics. Three of the speakers, one of the
organizers and three of the young mathematicians supported by
this grant are women.
